Keep calm and carry on eating: The science behind eating disorders

21/10/2013

I've already eaten my way through six slices of bread, four cookies and a yoghurt but my fingers still itch for more.

Image by

By James Bithell

"I've already eaten my way through six slices of bread, four cookies and a yoghurt but my fingers still itch for more. I try again to end the battle going on inside my head; my common sense screams for my appetite to back down whilst my stomach moans in defeat. I feel sick with guilt yet this doesn't stop me from tearing open another bag of crisps. I begin to wolf them down like an animal. 'I'll stop,' I promise myself, 'I'll go for a run after this, not eat for a good long while and everything will just reset ready for tomorrow.' Except, of course, it never does." This almost instinctive gorging originates from a time when, if it had been around, Aldi might have served mammoth burgers. In a world where food was not always readily available, it was those who could pile on the most pounds after a hunt who survived periods of starvation long enough to pass their large appetites on to the next generation. Whilst the majority of us can control this unfortunate result of natural selection, many struggle to ignore the urge to keep eating. Often associated with obesity, 'binge eating' describes the process of consuming very large amounts of food in a very short amount of time. In those whom suffer from binge eating disorder, there is usually a sense of loss of control and binges can occur on a very regular basis. Combine this with the desire to be healthy and the societal pressure to remain slim and you have the potential for rather an unhealthy relationship with food. Although the media might not have us believe it, around 50% of people with eating disorders are not classed as being anorexic or bulimic but as having an 'Eating Disorder Not Otherwise Specified'. This includes those with all the symptoms of anorexia but with a weight within the normal range, those with bulimic symptoms but suffering binges of a lower frequency than twice a week or someone who chews but does not swallow large amounts of food. It's these people, whose lives aren't viewed as being at immediate risk, who often go overlooked when it comes to treatment and with 1.6 million people affected by eating disorders across the UK, this hardly seems like something we can ignore. Earlier this month Beat, the UK's leading eating disorder charity, published the findings of a survey in which they asked 500 people about their eating disorders and how long they had to wait for treatment. 26% had to wait longer than six months before being referred to starting outpatient treatment and when given the statement 'The length of time I spent on a waiting list caused me to feel that I 'wasn't sick enough', 54% strongly agreed and 20% agreed. "I'd been to see two GPs," explained a friend when asked of her experience of seeking out treatment for bulimia. "One didn't understand and thought that my vomiting was related to stomach pain. She couldn't conceive it as a mental thing, only physical. The other GP said that eating disorders were on an upward rise and that because my bulimia didn't pose a life threat then there wasn't anything available to me in York." Eating disorders may not always be life-threatening yet they can still have a detrimental effect on both physical and mental wellbeing. One binge eating student said that they had a constant anxiety about what, where and when their next meal was going to be. "If I plan to go out for a meal with friends I'll spend the whole day in fear that I'll ruin my appetite beforehand and much of my valuable study time -or even time most people would spend relaxing with housemates- will be spent either exercising or wallowing in guilt." They turned to the Open Door Team which provides a free, confidential service of up to 6 sessions a week for University students and deals in a range of mental health disorders. After a few sessions though, the student found that "cognitive behaviour therapy wasn't my cup of tea for after all, my actions are never triggered by my emotions; I just respond to an innate urge to binge." This is similar to how author of 'Brain Over Binge', Kathryn Hansen, felt about her binges. Having been bulimic for 6 years, she overcame her disorder not through therapy, but through education; simply recognising the fact that her brain was wired to send out 'neurological junk' from brain 'regions inferior to [her] true self' enabled Kathryn to say 'no'. She likens 'urges' to an argumentative friend who, if you stop talking and listening to them, will eventually stop bothering you. Could this really be seen as a viable alternative to traditional therapy though? With the onset of the so-called 'obesity epidemic' there has been a huge increase in research on human response to food intake. Whilst the complexities of anorexia and bulimia are still poorly understood, the concept of 'food addiction' in binges is well covered. It's suggested that just as drugs such as cocaine can alter both dopamine and opioid receptors in the mesolimbic regions of the brain (or 'reward pathway')-, intermittent access to sugar can too. Dopamine is often referred to as the 'pleasure hormone', increasing motivation and enabling reinforcement. Unlike drugs, which increase dopamine release each time they're administered, the effect of eating palatable food usually wanes the more we have it, hence why the first bite of a Browns sandwich will always be the most enjoyable. However, a study carried out by US scientists in 2005 showed that when rats were allowed a daily binge on sugar, dopamine release did not decrease over time. Not only this, but dopamine levels have also been shown to spike simply at the sight and smell of food in binge eaters (where in non-binge-eaters they don't). In this particular study, it was found that dopamine levels increased in the caudate, a part of the brain 'involved in reinforcement of action potentially leading to reward, but not in the process of reward per se'." This 'reinforcement' could contribute to the urge to keep eating in binge eaters. What's just as interesting is that sugar deprivation, like that of morphine, nicotine and alcohol, can result in withdrawal symptoms and is associated with an imbalance of dopamine and acetylcholine in the nucleus accumbens (the 'reward centre' of the brain). Colantuoni, et al. found withdrawal behaviours such as teeth chattering, head shakes and forepore tremors have been in sugar-binging rats (given access to sugar for 12 hours/day) deprived of sugar as well as an increase in anxiety. When the rats were starved for 14 days and given access to a lever press through which they could 'ask' for more sugar, they used it 23% more than those who had only had access to sugar for 30 minutes/day (Avena, et al., 2005). In other words, the craving for sugar increases with the amount of time we abstain from eating it. This, then, might explain why most of us, including those with eating disorders, can't stick to a low-sugar diet. And it's not like we can turn to sweeteners to compensate for it either, for research suggests that artificial sweeteners do not activate the food reward pathways in the same fashion as natural sweeteners, for lack of caloric contribution tends to eliminate the post-ingestive component which acts independently of whether or not you're 'full'. Many of the self-help books accessible in the library encourage people with eating disorders to stick to and record a strict diet of eating 'little and often', even after having encountered a binge. Although this is often used as a form of cognitive behavioural therapy -in which you might analyse what or when binges occur to pinpoint emotional triggers- it might also be vital to restoring the correct balance of neurotransmitters in the nucleus accumbens, as well as reducing large cravings for sugar. A burning question for most people with an eating disorder though is not how it works, but how it developed in the first place. Although it's suggested that variations in specific genes, such as those for serotonin receptors, could be linked to anorexia, the complexity of our body's relationship with food means there can't be any one gene for the development of eating disorders. However, those who express particular traits, such as compulsivity, obsessive thinking, anxiety or negativity, are said to be more prone to their development, all of which being strongly influenced by your parent's genetics. With the development of neuroimaging technology, there's hope that this can be used to gain a greater insight into the neurological complexities which drive eating disorders. In 2009, Walter et al. published a paper in Nature discussing how brain imaging provides an insight into the neural dysfunction which leads to anorexia. Co-author Julie L. Fudge of the Department of Psychiatry & Neurobiology & Anatomy at the University of Rochester Medical Centre, notes that imaging studies suggest that individuals with anorexia have an imbalance between circuits which regulate reward and emotion and those associated with consequences and planning ahead in the brain. More recently, Brooks et al. (2012) used functional MRI to measure the brain response to sweet tastes in 28 women who had recovered from either bulimia or anorexia. Relative to the control group, who had never suffered from an eating disorder, those recovered from anorexia had a significantly diminished, and those recovered from bulimia, significantly elevated response to the taste of sucrose in the right anterior insula. Kaye, director of the UCSD Eating Disorders Treatment and Research Program notes, "this study confirms earlier studies by our group and others that establish a clear link between these disorders and neural processes in the insula, an area of the brain where taste is sensed and integrated with reward to help determine whether an individual hungry or full." There's hope that these studies will lead to better understanding of eating disorders which will result in better, more effective treatment in the future.
